The general principle here is that the simple, more broad statement (a) is always more probable than the more specific, conjunctive statement (b) which adds an additional condition.

This follows from basic probability theory - the probability of two independent events occurring together is the product of their individual probabilities, which will always be smaller than the probability of either one occurring alone.

So in cases like these, where we are given two options, one of which is just a subset of the other with an additional condition tacked on, the option without the extra condition is always more probable.
